Graphical abstract In this work, a series of CoAPSO-34(cobaltsilicoaluminophosphate, X = Co/Al, X = 0, 0.02, 0.05, 0.07, and 0.10) catalysts with different Co/Al molar ratio(X) were prepared for use in the chloromethane to olefin (CMTO) reaction to produce light olefins, such as ethylene and propylene. The CMTO reaction at 450 °C showed that CoAPSO-34(0.05) catalyst had the highest chloromethane conversion among the catalysts with a conversion of 78.75 % at the reaction time of 250 min. The catalytic lifetime increased with increasing Co/Al molar ratio up to 0.05 and then decreased with increasing Co/Al molar ratio up to 0.10. The deposition of coke originating from polymethylbenzene species is thought to be the main reason for deactivation of the catalysts. As the molar ratio of Co/Al increased from 0 to 0.05, the amount of acid site increased, although the textural property did not change. However, as the molar ratio of Co/Al increased from 0.05 to 0.10, the BET surface area and pore volume of the catalysts decreased sharply, in addition to the amount of acid sites. Hence, it is concluded that both the acidic properties and textural properties of the catalysts play a crucial role in determining the catalytic activities in the chloromethane to olefin reaction, resulting in the highest chloromethane conversion and light olefin selectivity over CoAPSO-34(0.05). Keywords Chloromethane to olefin (CMTO) Light olefin production CoAPSO-34 Co/Al molar ratio Deactivation behavior 1 Introduction Light olefins such as ethylene and propylene are important feedstocks in petrochemical industries because they are used in a variety of processes for making valuable chemicals like vinyl chloride, ethylene oxide, propylene oxide, styrene, acrylonitrile, and so on. Annual production rates of ethylene and propylene are expected to increase, because global demand for ethylene and propylene has been continuously increasing over the recent decades [1–7]. At present, ethylene production depends mainly on the thermal steam cracking of naphtha, which can also produce propylene as by-product, which contributes to 66 % of propylene production worldwide [1,2]. In the steam cracking process, hydrocarbons originating from crude oil are cracked at elevated temperature in tubular reactors to produce light olefins [4]. However, due to declining reserves of crude oil and the increasing demand for light olefins, investment in alternative routes to produce light olefin is necessary [2,8–10]. Meanwhile, only under 10 % of natural gas is currently used for chemical production, which means that the rest of the natural gas mainly consisting of methane is just burned as fuel [11]. Therefore, the research about efficient transformation of methane to valuable chemicals has been conducted for decades [12]. Several methods were announced to produce light olefins such as ethylene and propylene from methane such as one-step conversion and multistep conversion process. The one-step conversion includes oxidative or non-oxidative coupling of methane to hydrocarbons [12]. The one-step conversion method is not effective for large-scale industrial application because of its harsh reaction condition. The multistep conversion includes olefin production processes using syngas, methanol, and halogenated methane which are generated via methane activation [12]. Among these processes, the use of chloromethane, produced from methane via oxychlorination or chlorination, as a reactant has attracted much attention as an efficient process for the production of light olefin because there is no need to use syngas process which requires great amount of energy. It was previously reported that methanol to olefin reaction and chloromethane to olefin reaction proceed via same reaction mechanism called the hydrocarbon pool mechanism, in which the hydrocarbon pool consists mainly of polymethylbenzene species [13–16]. The polymethylbenzene species were formed resulting from reaction of methyl groups, which were produced by Brönsted acid sites inside the cage at the early stage of the reaction [17–20]. Such aromatic species inside the cage are active reaction intermediates that lead to the formation of light olefins. During the initial stages of the reaction before the complete buildup of polymethylbenzene, the formation of propylene has been known to occur mainly through the alkene methylation cycle, while the formation of ethylene has been known to occur through the aromatic cycle [21–23]. At steady state, ethylene and propylene are produced from the cracking of polymethylbenzene species inside the cage. It has also been reported that controlling the reaction temperature also affect the ratio of ethylene and propylene in the product stream [13,16]. For the production of light olefins, various aluminophosphate (AlPOs) and silicoaluminophosphate (SAPOs) that retained the microporous structure of P-Al or Si-P-Al have been widely investigated in the chloromethane to olefin (CMTO) process, like in the methanol to olefin process [24–29]. It has been reported that the topology and the acidic properties of the molecular sieves affected the conversion of chloromethane and the product distribution in the reaction [27]. Among the various molecular sieves reported, both ZSM-5 having MFI type structure and SAPO-34 having CHA type structure, showed excellent catalytic activity due to its large specific surface area, moderate acidity and shape selectivity, and superior hydrothermal stability. Although ZSM-5 catalyst used in the chloromethane to olefin reaction showed superior catalytic activities, a slow mass transfer rate of products released from the cage can cause further side reactions, which led to low selectivity of light olefins [30–34]. It is known that the small cages (4.7 Å) of SAPO-34 catalyst restrict the diffusion of heavy hydrocarbons, which leads to relatively high shape-selectivity to the target products, like light olefins [29,35]. However, when SAPO-34 molecular sieve is used in the chloromethane to olefin reaction, the main problem is rapid deactivation, due to further growth and deposition of active reaction intermediate such as polymethylbenzene species on the active site inside the cage [25,36–38]. The deposition of coke species caused serious degradation in the catalytic activities of the catalyst. For this reason, increasing the lifetime and the activity of the catalyst by reducing coke deposition is a key challenge that should be overcome in the chloromethane to olefin reaction for practical application. In an attempt to enhance the catalytic performance of SAPO-34 catalysts in the chloromethane to olefin reaction, incorporation of transition metal or heavy metal, including Ce, Co, Mg, Fe, and Mn into the SAPO-34 framework has been investigated [9,25,33,39,40]. With this incorporation of metal elements, MeAPSO-34 catalyst showed improved light olefin selectivity by modifying the acidity and the physical properties of SAPO-34 framework [5,39–41]. For example, Ni-incorporated SAPO-34 catalysts showed high ethylene selectivity of 90 %, and Sr-incorporated SAPO-34 catalysts showed ethylene and propylene selectivity of 89 % [42]. Also, Co-incorporated catalysts showed excellent catalytic activities according to the few previous reports [40,43]. However, most of the studies focused on the application of CoAPSO-34 catalyst on the methanol to olefin reaction and nitrogen monoxide decomposition reaction [40,43–49]. In the reference on the CoAPSO-34 catalyst applied to the chloromethane to olefin reaction, the reaction time was set shorter than that of methanol to olefin reaction [14]. This is presumed to be attributed to the lower conversion level of chloromethane, which could be related to the different proton affinity of each compounds (647 kJ/mol for chloromethane and 754 kJ/mol for methanol) [27,50]. It has been reported that methanol molecule is adsorbed more strongly with acid sites of zeolite framework than chloromethane molecule due to the presence of hydrogen bonding, which led to lower coverage of chloromethane molecules than methanol molecule on the surface [27]. Thus, it would be valuable to develop the CoAPSO-34 catalyst that maintains high catalytic activities for long reaction time, by conducting a study to find the optimal amount of cobalt species incorporated in the zeolite framework. Also, a study dealing with the long-term catalytic activities, stability and deactivation behavior of the catalyst with different amount of cobalt species is necessary for potential industrial application of the catalyst in the near future. In this work, a series of CoAPSO-34 catalysts were prepared by hydrothermal synthesis method with variation of the Co/Al molar ratio, which were employed to the chloromethane to olefin reaction. The effects of cobalt incorporation on the textural properties and the acidic properties of the catalysts were investigated. Also, the physicochemical properties of used catalysts were analyzed, and the effects of cobalt incorporation on the deactivation behavior of the catalysts were elucidated. The trend of coke deposition with the incorporation of cobalt species was demonstrated. The textural and morphological properties of the catalysts were examined by applying N2-adsorption-desorption, X-ray diffraction, and SEM analyses. In order to further analyze the physicochemical properties of the catalysts, various characterization techniques such as 27Al MAS NMR, 29Si MAS NMR, NH3-TPD, UV–vis, and X-ray fluorescence spectroscopy analyses were conducted. 2 Experimental 2.1 Catalyst preparation A series of CoAPSO-34 catalysts with different Co/Al molar ratio were prepared using the following experimental procedure. The molar composition of synthesis solution was 1.0Al2O3:1.0P2O5:0.36SiO2:58H2O:1.0TEAOH:1.0Morpholine:XCo2O3 (X = 0, 0.02. 0.05, 0.07, and 0.10). The two species of templates (TEAOH and morpholine) were used in this work to improve the catalytic activity and stability [6,51]. In detail, the calculated amount of aluminum isopropoxide (≥98 %, Sigma-Aldrich) and phosphoric acid (85 %, Samchun) were dissolved in deionized water under vigorous stirring at 60 °C for 4 h. After that, Ludox HS-40 (40 %, Sigma-Aldrich) was added to solution, followed by the addition of cobalt nitrate hexahydrate (≥98 %, Sigma-Aldrich). Finally, tetraethylammonium hydroxide (TEAOH, 35 wt% in H2O, Sigma-Aldrich) and morpholine (≥ 99 %, Sigma-Aldrich), which were used as structure directing agents, were added to this mixture sequentially, and then stirred for 2 h. The final precursor gel was transferred into Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave and crystallized at 200 °C for 48 h under autogenous pressure. The crystals were filtered, repeatedly washed with deionized water, dried at 80 °C for 12 h, and then calcined in air at 550 °C for 6 h to remove the template and impurities. The obtained catalysts were denoted as CoAPSO-34(X, X = 0, 0.02, 0.05, 0.07, and 0.10), where X represented the Co/Al molar ratio. Note that SAPO-34 is named as CoAPSO-34(0) catalyst for uniformity of labeling. 2.2 Characterization Textural properties of CoAPSO-34(X = Co/Al, X = 0, 0.02, 0.05, 0.07, and 0.10) catalysts were obtained by nitrogen adsorption-desorption measurements (BELSORP-mini II, BEL Japan). Before the analyses, all the catalysts were pretreated at 150 °C for 2 h with a rotary vacuum pump to eliminate physically absorbed species and moisture. Surface areas of the catalysts were calculated by the BET equation. The chemical composition and Co/Al molar ratio of calcined catalysts were determined by X-ray fluorescence (XRF) spectroscopy analyses (S8-Tiger, Bruker). In order to examine the crystalline structures of the catalysts, X-ray diffraction (XRD) measurements (D-MAX2500-PC, Rigaku) were conducted. XRD patterns were taken with the Cu-Kα radiation (λ =1.541 Å) operated at 50 kV and 100 mA. Field emission scanning electron microscopy (FE-SEM) analysis (JSM-6700F, JEOL Ltd) was performed to investigate the morphology of the catalysts. In order to obtain the amount of carbon species deposited inside the catalysts after 250 min-reaction, elemental analyses (TruSpec Micro CHNS, LECO) were conducted. In order to determine the coordination state of cobalt species of CoAPSO-34(X = Co/Al, X = 0.02, 0.05, 0.07, and 0.10) catalysts, ultraviolet visible (UV–vis) spectroscopy analyses (Mega-900, Scinco) were conducted within the range of 200−800 nm. Chemical states of aluminum species in the catalysts were examined by magic angle spinning nuclear magnetic resonance (27Al MAS NMR) spectrometry (Bruker Avance II, Bruker). The chemical shifts of the Al signals were referenced to Al(NO3)3, and a signal pulse was used to obtain the 27Al MAS NMR spectra. 29Si MAS NMR was also conducted to elucidate the chemical states of silicon species in the catalysts using the same instrument as 27Al MAS NMR in a 4 mm MAS probe. The resonance frequency of 27Al MAS NMR and 29Si MAS NMR is 130 MHz and 99 MHz, respectively. The acidic properties of calcined catalysts and catalysts after 250 min-reaction were investigated by NH3-temperature programmed desorption (NH3-TPD) measurement (BELCAT, BEL Japan). First, 0.05 g of each catalyst was charged into a quartz U-shaped TPD cell. In order to conduct pretreatment, the temperature was increased to 200 °C for 2 h under flowing He (50 ml/min) at a constant ramping rate of 10 °C/min. After cooling to 50 °C, the catalyst was put in a gas flow of NH3 (50 ml/min) for saturation. After the saturation of catalyst with NH3 for 30 min, the catalyst was exposed to He flow (50 ml/min) to eliminate physisorbed species at 100 °C for 1 h. Finally, a TPD profile was acquired while the catalyst was heated from 100 to 700 °C at a ramping rate of 5 °C/min under a flow of He (30 ml/min). 2.3 Catalytic test Light olefin production from the transformation of chloromethane was carried out in a continuous flow fixed-bed quartz reactor at 450 °C at atmospheric pressure. Each catalyst (0.2 g), sieved in 0.18−0.25 mm, was loaded into the reactor. The reaction temperature was controlled by a thermocouple placed just above the catalyst. Total inlet flow rate including reactant (chloromethane, CH3Cl) and internal standard (nitrogen, N2) was controlled to 13 ml/min with the volume ratio of CH3Cl:N2 (1:4.2). Note that internal and external mass transfer limitations of the catalyst particles at our experimental conditions are negligible which is calculated by using the Weisz-Prater criteria and the Mears criteria [50]. Outlet stream was heated at 150 °C to avoid the condensation of the products, and analyzed using on-line gas chromatograph (6890 N/G1530 N, Agilent Technologies) equipped with HP Plot-Q capillary column and Carboxen 1000 packed column. FID (Flame ionization detector) and TCD (Thermal conductivity detector) were used to analyze methane (CH4), ethylene (C2H4), ethane (C2H6), propylene (C3H6), and propane (C3H8), and chloromethane (CH3Cl) and nitrogen (N2), respectively. Production of light olefin from chloromethane proceeds with change of mole number in reaction. Therefore, GC data obtained from experiment should be calibrated by introducing internal standard factor, α (Eq. (1)), where n(N2) is the amount of nitrogen in moles. (3) S j = n j o u t l e t Ʃ n j o u t l e t × 100 , % (4) Y j = X C M × S j , % 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Catalyst characterization Nitrogen adsorption-desorption measurements were conducted to analyze the textural properties of the CoAPSO-34(X = Co/Al, X = 0, 0.02, 0.05, 0.07, and 0.10) catalysts (data not shown). It was found that all the catalysts showed I-type isotherms, which were attributed to well-developed micropore [37]. H1-type hysteresis loop was also obtained in the isotherms of the catalysts, which indicates the presence of microporous structure. The detailed textural properties of the catalysts are summarized. As shown in Table 1 , specific surface area (530 m2/g) and pore volume (0.27 cm3/g) were quite similar when Co/Al molar ratio increased from 0 to 0.05. However, the increment of Co/Al molar ratio from 0.05 to 0.10 resulted in a decrement of specific surface area from 530 m2/g to 427 m2/g. It is also interesting to note that the pore volume of the catalyst decreased from 0.27 cm3/g to 0.22 cm3/g with increasing Co/Al molar ratio from 0.05 to 0.10. This might be explained by the proposal that the addition of excess amount of cobalt prevented SAPO-34 from developing pore structure during the crystallization process. Meanwhile, regardless of the amount of cobalt incorporated in the catalysts, the average pore diameter of the CoAPSO-34(X) catalysts showed no consistent trend. The Co/Al molar ratio of the catalysts were calculated from the results of X-ray fluorescence (XRF) spectroscopy as shown in Table 1. The obtained catalysts and initial gel compositions were observed to be relatively close to each other. Among the catalysts, CoAPSO-34(0.10) catalyst, which retained the highest amount of cobalt in the starting gel showed the highest Co/Al molar ratio of 0.13. Although all the starting gels were prepared with the same Si/Al molar ratio, it was observed that with increasing Co/Al molar ratio of starting gel, the silicon content of the calcined catalysts decreased, which indicates that different amounts of silicon were incorporated into the framework. Such difference in the chemical composition of the calcined catalysts means that the presence of cobalt species in the starting gel has an effect on the silicon distribution into the SAPO-34 framework during the crystallization process [25]. The crystalline structures of CoAPSO-34(X = Co/Al, X = 0, 0.02, 0.05, 0.07, and 0.10) catalysts were examined by X-ray diffraction (XRD) measurements. As shown in Fig. 1 , all the catalysts exhibited diffraction peaks of SAPO-34 at 2θ = 9.8°, 12.9°, and 20.5°, corresponding to [100], [10 1 ¯ ], and [20 1 ¯ ] crystal plane, respectively [52]. The peak intensity of SAPO-34 gradually decreased with increasing Co/Al molar ratio of the catalysts, which is attributed to the fact that during crystallization process, the incorporation of cobalt into SAPO-34 framework affected the crystallinity of the catalysts. Diffraction peaks arising from the impurity phase, such as cobalt oxide, were not detected in the catalysts, which means that cobalt was mostly incorporated in the framework of SAPO-34 zeolite structure. It has been reported that when TEAOH was used as a main structure directing agent for the crystallization process, it can cause co-crystallization of SAPO-5 (AFI type) and SAPO-34 (CHA type) phase [51]. However, in this work, calcined catalysts did not show diffraction peaks that were attributed to SAPO-5 phase. From the previous report, it can be inferred that the introduction of cobalt species prior to the addition of structure directing agent prevented the formation of impurity phase such as SAPO-5 [43]. It is interesting to note that compared to the CoAPSO-34(0) catalysts, for CoAPSO-34(X = Co/Al, X = 0.02, 0.05, 0.07, and 0.10), which series contain cobalt in the framework, with increasing Co/Al molar ratio, the XRD diffraction peak at around 9.8° shifted to lower diffraction angle. It has been reported that the shift of diffraction peak to lower angle implies an increment in the lattice parameter as a result of metal incorporation [5,14,25]. This distortion of the shape of unit cell may stem from a longer CoO bond distance than the AlO bond distance. The unit cell parameters of CoAPSO-34 catalysts were obtained assuming R3m symmetry in a hexagonal system. As can be seen from Table 2 , value of a-axis increased and the volume of unit cell decreased with the introduction of cobalt. The difference in unit cell parameter was caused by the incorporation of cobalt ion which is larger than aluminum ion [14]. Such increment, observed experimentally, provides evidence that cobalt incorporation into the zeolite framework has taken place. The morphological features of the CoAPSO-34(X = Co/Al, X = 0, 0.02, 0.05, 0.07, and 0.10) catalysts were elucidated by field emission scanning electron microscopy (FE-SEM) analysis. As shown in Fig. 2 , the cubic-like hexagonal structure could be clearly observed in the SEM images of all the catalysts, which is quite similar to pure CHA type structure [14]. The crystal size is in the range of 2−5 μm. It is worth noting that the completeness of crystal shape was enhanced with increasing the cobalt loading. Thus, based on the XRD, BET, and SEM results, it can be inferred that as a consequence of the incorporation of cobalt into the framework, the physical properties of the catalysts were changed. As summarized in Table 1, Co/Al molar ratios of the catalysts that were calculated from the EDX results. It was found that the elemental compositions of the initial gel were quite similar to the Co/Al molar ratios of the catalysts. Based on the characterization results, it can be summarized that during crystallization process, cobalt was successfully incorporated into the SAPO-34 framework of the catalysts. In order to elucidate the chemical state of aluminum species in the CoAPSO-34(X = Co/Al, X = 0, 0.02, 0.05, 0.07, and 0.10) catalysts, 27Al MAS NMR analyses were performed. As shown in Fig. 3 , all the catalysts showed a sharp peak at 37 ppm, which is assigned to the typical signal of aluminum in a tetrahedral environment Al(4P) for CHA type zeolites [25]. It was observed that the peak intensity for tetra-coordinated aluminum gradually decreased with increasing Co/Al molar ratio. It might be understood that the chemical state of aluminum species changed during crystallization process due to the incorporation of cobalt species into the zeolite framework [25]. In order to examine the chemical state of silicon species in the CoAPSO-34(X = Co/Al, X = 0, 0.02, 0.05, 0.07, and 0.10) catalysts, 29Si MAS NMR analyses were performed. It has been reported that silicon atom can be incorporated into the framework by two different substitution mechanisms [53]. The first, denoted as SM2 mechanism, is the substitution of single phosphorus atom by single silicon atom, which causes the formation of Brönsted acid sites. The second mechanism, denoted as SM3 mechanism, is the double substitution of neighboring aluminum and phosphorus atoms by two silicon atoms, which leads to the formation of stronger Brönsted acid sites [53]. It is known that silicon incorporation by SM2 mechanism could occur when the Si/Al molar ratio was low in the starting gel [53]. It is also known that the SM2 substitution mechanism causes the formation of Si(4Al) species, denoted as isolated silicon species [6]. As shown in Fig. 4 , with increasing Si/Al molar ratio in the starting gel, Si(3Al), Si(2Al), Si(1Al), and Si(0Al) species (silicon islands) were formed simultaneously resulting from the SM3 mechanism [6,53]. It is recognized that the silicon coordination has significant effect on the acidity of the catalysts, which acidity was enhanced in the order of Si(0Al) < Si(4Al) < Si(3Al) < Si(2Al) < Si(1Al) [53]. It has been reported that the strength of the acid sites formed at the border of the silicon islands is higher than that of the acid sites generated by the isolated silicon atoms [54,55]. Thus, it can be inferred that when SM2 mechanism take place exclusively, a higher number of acid sites could be generated; while when SM2 and SM3 mechanism take place simultaneously, lesser but stronger acid sites could be formed. As shown in Fig. 4, all the catalysts contained peaks at -95.2, -97, -100, -104.3, and -109.8 ppm, which can be attributed to Si(4Al), Si(3Al), Si(2Al), Si(1Al), and Si(0Al) species, respectively, suggesting that silicon atoms were incorporated into the framework by the routes of both SM2 and SM3 mechanism. Compared with CoAPSO-34(0) catalyst, which did not contain cobalt species, no additional peak was observed in the spectra of CoAPSO-34(X = Co/Al, X = 0.02, 0.05, 0.07, and 0.10), indicating that upon cobalt incorporation, no new silicon species were formed. It has been reported that in the case of Co2+ incorporation into the framework, Al3+ ion neighboring a Si4+ atom cannot be substituted according to the Lowenstein rule [56]. This means that during crystallization process, the Si-O-Co bond cannot form due to the charge vicinity [56]. It is worth noting that peak intensity of Si(2Al), Si(1Al), and Si(0Al) corresponding to silicon islands increased with increasing Co/Al molar ratio of the catalysts. However, as the amount of cobalt species in the catalyst increased, the peak intensity of Si(4Al) and Si(3Al) decreased. From these results, it is noticeable that more silicon islands were formed in the framework with increasing Co/Al molar ratio of the catalyst despite a small amount of silicon content. Therefore, it can be summarized that cobalt incorporation affected the chemical environment of silicon atoms. Also, it is expected that the acidity and the catalytic activities of the catalysts changed resulting from the different chemical environment of silicon atoms caused by the incorporation of cobalt into the framework. In order to investigate the acidic properties of the CoAPSO-34(X = Co/Al, X = 0, 0.02, 0.05, 0.07, and 0.10) catalysts, NH3-temperature programmed desorption (NH3-TPD) measurement were performed. It is well known that SAPO-34 catalysts with different acidic properties showed different catalytic activities and coke formation trend in chloromethane to olefin reaction [14,25]. It has been reported that the catalyst having large amount of strong acid sites showed excellent catalytic activities in the reaction because it can generate active reaction intermediate actively, as well as promotes coke formation [14,25]. Thus, elucidating the effect of cobalt incorporation on the acidic properties of the catalysts is required. As shown in Fig. 5 , the deconvolution was performed to separate the overlapped desorption peaks of NH3 which was summarized in Table 3 . According to the literature, SAPO-34 catalysts showed three desorption peaks at the temperature around 200 °C, 300 °C, and 400 °C, which were assigned to the NH3 desorbed from weak, medium, and strong acidic sites, respectively [25]. The weak acid site at lower temperature was related to desorbed NH3 from the surface hydroxyl groups (P-OH and Si-OH) [57]. The medium acid site at around 300 °C was attributed to desorbed NH3 from the weak Brönsted acid site (Si-OH-Al) [57]. The strong acid site at above 400 °C arises from NH3 desorbed from the strong Brönsted acid site (Si-OH-Al) [57]. As mentioned before, the acidic strength of Brönsted acid sites was determined by silicon distribution in the catalysts, so that it can be said that the acidic strength of the catalysts and the distribution of the weak, medium, and strong acid sites, must change as a function of the amount of cobalt species in the SAPO-34. According to the quantified NH3-TPD results summarized in Table 3, it is worth noting that the amount of strong acid sites increased from 1.335 mmol/g to 1.779 mmol/g with increasing Co/Al molar ratio up to the value of 0.05 and then decreased to 0.909 mmol/g with further increasing Co/Al molar ratio up to 0.10. This may stem from lesser silicon incorporation and the formation of more silicon islands in CoAPSO-34 catalysts with relatively high Co/Al molar ratio, as explained in the 29Si MAS NMR results. As mentioned above, the strong acid sites are known to be more important than the weak and medium acid sites in the chloromethane to olefin reaction, because they play an active role in producing active reaction intermediate through consecutive alkylation, which called as the hydrocarbon pool mechanism [15]. Therefore, it can be claimed that CoAPSO-34(X = Co/Al, X = 0.02 and 0.05) catalysts which retained a higher amount of active sites could present superior catalytic activities than the CoAPSO-34(0) catalysts. In order to determine the coordination state of cobalt species, ultraviolet visible (UV–vis) spectroscopy analyses for CoAPSO-34(X = Co/Al, X = 0.02, 0.05, 0.07, and 0.10) catalysts were conducted. As demonstrated in Fig. 6 , all the catalysts exhibited three peaks at 540 (1), 585 (ν2), and 626 (ν2) nm, which are attributed to the d-d transitions (4A2(F) → 4T1(P)) of divalent cobalt ions in tetrahedral coordination [56]. It was observed that the peak intensity of cobalt at tetrahedral site increased with increasing Co/Al molar ratio of the catalysts. These results show that cobalt ions were successfully incorporated into the framework of the catalysts. Upon calcination in air, the color of the catalysts changed from dark blue to green, which indicates the formation of cobalt(III) sites, as reported in the literature [56,58]. 3.2 Catalytic performance of the CoAPSO-34(X) catalysts The catalytic performance of the CoAPSO-34(X = Co/Al, X = 0, 0.02, 0.05, 0.07, and 0.10) catalysts in the light olefin production using chloromethane are shown in Fig. 7 . The first analysis of the products obtained at 50 min-reaction time showed higher chloromethane conversion (≥85 %) for all cobalt-containing catalysts than for CoAPSO-34(0) catalyst, indicating the higher initial catalytic activity of the former catalysts. It can also be seen from the result that CoAPSO-34(0) catalyst goes through an initial activation stage before its maximum chloromethane conversion which is different from the behavior of cobalt containing catalysts. This phenomenon has been reported from several studies about methanol to olefin and chloromethane to olefin reaction [21,50]. Low chloromethane conversion at the initial stage of the reaction could be closely related to the formation of alkylaromatic species which act as active reaction intermediate [50,59]. Although conversion of chloromethane was low at the initial stage of the reaction, selectivity of target products (ethylene and propylene) was relatively high. It has been reported recently that autocatalytic reaction between chloromethane and other hydrocarbons occurred inside the cage simultaneously with hydrocarbon pool mechanism [50]. Thus, the target products can be produced continuously during initial activation period. Also, it can be inferred from the NH3-temperature programmed desorption (NH3-TPD) (Fig. 5) that relatively shorter initial activation period of CoAPSO-34(X, X = 0.02, 0.05, 0.07, and 0.10) catalyst was attributed to slightly stronger acidity compared to that of CoAPSO-34(0) catalysts [59]. It is interesting to note that CoAPSO-34(0.02) and CoAPSO-34(0.05) catalysts showed higher chloromethane conversion during time on stream of 250 min than CoAPSO-34(0) catalyst. This is also explained by the NH3-temperature programmed desorption (NH3-TPD) results (Table 3) that the incorporation of the proper amount of cobalt species caused the additional generation of active sites which is essential for the hydrocarbon-pool mechanism. It means that cobalt incorporation into a SAPO-34 framework can be helpful in maintaining high chloromethane conversion of the catalysts. It was interesting to note that compared to CoAPSO-34(0) catalyst, the chloromethane conversion of the catalysts which contain excess amount of cobalt species (CoAPSO-34(0.07) and CoAPSO-34(0.10)) decreased rapidly. As discussed in the NH3-TPD and 29Si MAS NMR results in Section 3.1, the incorporation of excess amount of cobalt species favored the formation of silicon islands, which leads to the production of lesser but stronger acid sites. It is well known that strong acid sites promote the formation of active reaction intermediate but also facilitate coke formation, which leads to rapid deactivation of catalyst [29]. The decrement of target product yield and increment of occupied active sites are explained by the fact that the additional alkylation or hydrogen transfer reaction occurred inside the cage [29,59]. Thus, conversion of CoAPSO-34(X, X = 0.07 and 0.10) catalysts dropped sharply compared to the other catalysts with less cobalt loading. As an additional explanation for the drastic decrease in chloromethane conversion, accessibility to the active sites of the catalysts with a small amount of active sites could be easily blocked by coke deposition since the absolute number of acid sites is small. Hence, it can be deduced that the decrement of active site and increment of acidity both affected fast deactivation of CoAPSO-34(X = Co/Al, X = 0.07 and 0.10) catalysts. In summary, it is considered that as the amount of cobalt species incorporated into the catalyst increased, the amount of active site increased, thus improving the catalytic activities. Therefore, in terms of the perspective of minimizing deactivation mechanism, both porous structure and acidic properties (strength and the amount of active site) played an important role in the chloromethane to olefin reaction. As listed in Table 4 , the detailed product distribution collected after 100 min and 250 min of reaction time revealed that the selectivity of several products varies with time on stream and the amount of cobalt incorporated. The yield of target products (ethylene and propylene) over time on stream was listed on supporting information (Table S1). At a reaction time of 100 min, ethylene and propylene were produced as the main products. Paraffin products such as methane, ethane, and propane were also produced as the byproducts. For all the catalysts tested, the selectivity of ethylene increased with increasing reaction time and attained 57–67 % at the time on stream of 250 min. On the other hand, the selectivity of propylene decreased with increasing reaction time and decreased to 20–34 % at the time on stream of 250 min. It can be inferred that the variation in the selectivity of light olefin could result from the physicochemical modification of the catalysts during the reaction. It has been reported that during the chloromethane to olefin reaction, the pore mouth and channel of the catalysts can be partially or totally blocked by hydrocarbon pool intermediates, such as phenanthrene, pyrene, and methylnaphthalenes [5,29,60]. Hence, it is expected that the diffusivity of propylene decreased more quickly than ethylene with time on stream and subsequently cracking of propylene could occur. Also, it is known that chloromethane to olefin reaction occurs through the two initial path of the dual cycle mechanism as mentioned above [21,50]. Thus, it can be inferred that relatively higher selectivity of propylene at the initial stage of the reaction compared to that at the reaction time of 250 min might arise from the dominating autocatalytic reaction cycle compared to the aromatic cycle [21]. However, after sufficient amount of alkylaromatic species was formed inside the cage, aromatic cycle dominates which led to the change of target product distribution. With the production of light olefins, paraffin products such as methane, ethane, and propane were also produced with low selectivity. The selectivity of paraffin products showed no consistent trend with regard to the amount of cobalt incorporated into the catalysts except for CoAPSO-34(0.10) which contains the highest amount of cobalt. An increment in the methane selectivity of CoAPSO-34(0.10) catalysts with time on stream may also arise from the pore blockage due to coke formation, according to the previous reports [25,29]. Comparing the catalytic performances of chloromethane conversion over the catalysts, cobalt incorporation affected the light olefin selectivity. With increasing Co/Al molar ratio of the catalysts, the selectivity of ethylene increased, although the selectivity of propylene decreased. It was also reported that the stronger acidity of the catalyst must be related to higher ethylene selectivity [13]. In the case of cobalt-containing catalysts, it was observed from the 29Si MAS NMR results that the incorporation of cobalt species caused the formation of silicon islands in the framework. The presence of strong acid sites created from silicon atoms at the border of silicon islands could explain the higher ethylene/propylene ratio of CoAPSO-34(X = Co/Al, X = 0.02, 0.05, 0.07, and 0.10) catalysts than that of CoAPSO-34(0) catalyst. It can be inferred from the above results that due to the incorporation of cobalt species into the framework, methylbenzene species with a lower number of methyl groups formed inside the cage more actively than those with a higher number of methyl groups. In summary, the change in the selectivity distribution of target products (ethylene and propylene) over reaction time and Co/Al molar ratio is considered to be attributed to the combination of two significant factors: the change of porous structure and acidic properties [59]. The correlation between the acidic property and ultimate chloromethane conversion of the catalysts was shown in Fig. 8 . It should be noted that the amount of active sites increased with increasing Co/Al molar ratio up to 0.05 and decreased with increasing Co/Al molar ratio up to 0.10. Based on these results, it is considered that the incorporation of the optimum amount of cobalt species into the framework caused to enhance the catalytic activity by further generating the active sites. However, the incorporation of excess amount of cobalt species favored the formation of silicon islands instead of isolated silicon which affected the amount and strength of the active sites. These results led to the enhanced ethylene selectivity over reaction time and drastic decrease of chloromethane conversion at the reaction time of 250 min over CoAPSO-34(X, X = 0.07 and 0.10) catalysts. Among the catalysts, CoAPSO-34(0.05) catalysts with the largest amount of active sites showed the highest chloromethane conversion at the time on stream of 250 min, since the addition of cobalt led to the enhanced acidic properties by modifying the physicochemical properties of the catalyst. 3.3 Analysis of the post-reaction CoAPSO-34(X) catalysts The difference in chloromethane conversion and product selectivity over the catalysts with different amount of cobalt incorporated have been clearly observed. From the above results, it can be concluded that physicochemical properties of the catalysts changed over reaction time with certain tendency. Also, the amount of cobalt species incorporated in the framework can affect the decreasing rate of chloromethane conversion with time on stream. It is known that the trend of coke formation and deactivation rate were closely related to the incorporation of metal species into the zeolite framework during the chloromethane to olefin reaction [14]. The hydrocarbon species evolved from active reaction intermediate species will gradually lose their function as reaction intermediate and block the micropore and active sites. Thus, quantitative calculation of the amount of coke species deposited inside the cage after the reaction is important to determine the degree of catalyst deactivation. In order to elucidate the effect of cobalt incorporation on the porous structure and acidic properties of the post-reaction catalysts, various characterization techniques were conducted, such as nitrogen adsorption-desorption, elemental analyses, and NH3 temperature programmed desorption analyses. Nitrogen adsorption-desorption measurements were conducted to examine the textural properties of CoAPSO-34(X = Co/Al, X = 0, 0.02, 0.05, 0.07, and 0.10) catalysts collected after being used in the for 250 min. As summarized in Table 5 , all the catalysts retained very small surface area and pore volume compared to the calcined catalysts. It has been reported that alkylated aromatics trapped inside the cage of zeolite catalysts condense to a greater extent through aromatization reaction which leads to decrease of surface area and pore volume [29,61]. Among the catalysts, CoAPSO-34(0.05) catalyst which showed the highest chloromethane conversion at the reaction time of 250 min retained the highest surface area. The pore diameter of all the post-reaction CoAPSO-34 catalysts increased after reaction, since blockage of small pore by coke deposition caused the increase in the average value of pore diameter. In order to calculate the amount of carbon species deposited inside the catalysts after 250 min-reaction, elemental analyses were conducted as listed in Table 5. The results show that the amount of coke species was changing depending on Co/Al molar ratio of the catalysts. It was observed that the amount of carbon species decreased with increasing Co/Al molar ratio up to 0.05 and increased with increasing Co/Al molar ratio up to 0.10. From these results, it can be inferred that the incorporation of the proper amount of cobalt species could be the reason for the enhanced coke resistance of catalysts. However, catalysts with excess amount of cobalt species (CoAPSO-34(0.07) and CoAPSO-34(0.10)) were vulnerable to coke deposition inside the cage due to inferior porous structure. In order to compare the acidic properties of the calcined and post-reaction catalysts, NH3-temperature programmed desorption (NH3-TPD) measurement was performed. The deconvolution was performed to separate the overlapped desorption peaks of NH3. According to the summarized results in Table 6 , the amount of weak, medium, and strong acid sites decreased after 250 min-reaction. More precisely, the amount of strong acid sites which are known as the main active site for the chloromethane to olefin reaction decreased sharply after 250 min-reaction, attributed to the deposition of heavy aromatic species formed during reaction time. The amount of residual strong acid site increased with increasing Co/Al molar ratio up to 0.05 and decreased with increasing Co/Al molar ratio up to 0.10. Such difference in the catalysts allows the inference that the incorporation of the proper amount of cobalt species into the framework delayed the blockage of active site. However, the incorporation of excess amount of cobalt species hindered the formation of strong acid sites during the crystallization step. In addition, blockage of acid sites during reaction time occurred more actively over CoAPSO-34(X, X = 0.07 and 0.10) catalysts due to inferior textural properties. Thus, the amount of strong acid sites of CoAPSO-34(X, X = 0.07 and 0.10) catalysts after 250 min-reaction were less than that of the CoAPSO-34(0) catalysts. From these results, it can be concluded that during the reaction time of 250 min, the enhanced textural properties and acidic properties of post-reaction catalysts due to cobalt incorporation must be closely related to the excellent catalytic performance of the CoAPSO-34(0.05) catalyst, compared to the CoAPSO-34(0) catalyst. 4 Conclusion In this study, a series of CoAPSO-34(X = Co/Al, X = 0, 0.02, 0.05, 0.07, and 0.10) catalysts with different Co/Al molar ratio was prepared for the production of light olefins from chloromethane. The effect of the Co/Al molar ratio on the physicochemical properties and catalytic performances of the catalysts were elucidated. The incorporation of cobalt species into SAPO-34 framework give rise to the change in unit cell parameter and silicon chemical environment, resulting in volcano-shaped trend of the number of strong acid sites with respect to Co/Al molar ratio. Textural properties of CoAPSO-34(X, X = 0.02 and 0.05) catalysts retained sufficiently high enough to produce target products and heavy hydrocarbon species formed from additional reaction of active reaction intermediates. In the chloromethane to olefin reaction, both the conversion of chloromethane at time on stream of 250 min and the amount of active sites showed volcano-shaped trend with respect to the Co/Al molar ratio. Hence, an optimum amount of cobalt incorporation into the framework was required for the continuous production of light olefins, indicating that the acidic and textural properties modified by cobalt incorporation played an important role in determining the catalytic activity in the reaction. Elemental analyses of deactivated catalysts showed that coke species were deposited inside the cage after 250 min-reaction and the amount of coke species was different depending on Co/Al molar ratio. Among the catalysts, CoAPSO-34(0.05) catalysts with the largest amount of active sites and excellent textural property was found to be the most active and stable catalyst in the chloromethane to olefin reaction. coredata.dc:description: In this work, a series of CoAPSO-34(cobaltsilicoaluminophosphate, X = Co/Al, X = 0, 0.02, 0.05, 0.07, and 0.10) catalysts with different Co/Al molar ratio(X) were prepared for use in the chloromethane to olefin (CMTO) reaction to produce light olefins, such as ethylene and propylene. The CMTO reaction at 450 °C showed that CoAPSO-34(0.05) catalyst had the highest chloromethane conversion among the catalysts with a conversion of 78.75 % at the reaction time of 250 min. The catalytic lifetime increased with increasing Co/Al molar ratio up to 0.05 and then decreased with increasing Co/Al molar ratio up to 0.10. The deposition of coke originating from polymethylbenzene species is thought to be the main reason for deactivation of the catalysts. As the molar ratio of Co/Al increased from 0 to 0.05, the amount of acid site increased, although the textural property did not change. However, as the molar ratio of Co/Al increased from 0.05 to 0.10, the BET surface area and pore volume of the catalysts decreased sharply, in addition to the amount of acid sites. Hence, it is concluded that both the acidic properties and textural properties of the catalysts play a crucial role in determining the catalytic activities in the chloromethane to olefin reaction, resulting in the highest chloromethane conversion and light olefin selectivity over CoAPSO-34(0.05).
coredata.dc:title: Effects of Co/Al molar ratio in CoAPSO-34 catalysts on the physicochemical property and catalytic performance in the chloromethane to light olefins reaction
